title: Carlo Dalla Vedova gives thumbs up to Rio as a sailing venue
text:
Carlo Dalla Vedova gives thumbs up to Rio as a sailing venue Competitors during the windsurfing test event in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in August 2015 By Ashok Purohit October 21, 2015 
Despite widespread concerns surrounding water pollution at the venue for sailing events at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, the president of the RS:X class, Carlo Dalla Vedova, is confident that the windsurfing event will be a smooth success at the Games. 
Sailors and coaches have been questioning the quality of the water of Guanabara Bay, the venue for all the sailing events, alleging that illegal dumping of sewage into the water body is a major worry. 
In his remarks to Muscat Daily on Monday, Vedova said, “Water pollution has been an issue, but the organisers have assured us of cleaning up the bay in time for the Olympics. I was there for a test event in August. The organisers told me that the water will be fully clean and safe by early next year.” 
Carlo Dalla Vedova 
Rio de Janeiro will host the Games from August 5-21 next year. 
During the sailing test events held at the venue in August, the sailors had complained about floating debris and allegedly found dead animals in the water. 
Vedova, however, insisted that he is pleased with the progress made to clean the water and 'trusted the Brazilian organisers to deliver clean water'. 
With less than a year to go for the big event, the Italian chief of the world windsurfing body said, “The venue at Guanabara Bay is not that dirty as reports have projected it to be. We had successful test events there and I personally love the place. 
“I think the protests in Brazil over water pollution is a political matter. I am not too concerned and I am confident that Rio will deliver the best windsurfing competition.” 
During a test event in Rio in August, South Korean windsurfer Wonwoo Choo, ho is also participating in the worlds at the Musannah Sports City, had been hospitalised after catching a virus, with his coach alleging that his ward may have fallen sick due to an issue with the water. 
Later, the International Sailing Federation (ISAF) and the Rio 2016 organisers said that there was no direct evidence to suggest that the sailor's illness was caused by contact with the water. 
When Rio pipped Madrid, Chicago and Tokyo in 2009 to host the 2016 Olympics, one of the key promises in its winning bid was to cut pollution in Guanabara Bay by 80 per cent. 
But according to recent media reports, the Brazilian government is struggling to achieve it and may not be able to clean up the venue in time for the Games. 
Vedova, however, maintained that the Rio Games would be a success despite the misgivings. 
2017 worlds to be hosted by Japan 
Vedova presided over the annual general meeting at the Musannah Sports City on the sidelines of the RS:X World Windsurfing Championships. 
Among the major decisions taken was the awarding of the 2017 event. The worlds will be hosted by Enoshima, Japan, the same venue for sailing during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. 
Also, the youth worlds will be held in Torbole, Italy and the European championships in Marseille, France. 
Speaking about the development plans, Vedova said that 'the sport is the entry door for sailing and is practised in nearly 50 countries'. 
“We want to take the sport to newer places. The world championship in Oman is part of our efforts to spread the game and we are happy that the event has attracted top sailors from nearly 40 countries,” he said. Similar content
